Award.AwardTitle: SHINE Workshop Coordination for the Period during January 1, 2010 to December 31, 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award is for the oversight and management of the annual science workshops offered by the SHINE (Solar, Heliospheric, and INterplanetary Environment) program community over the five years. SHINE unites the U.S. scientists within the solar, interplanetary, and heliospheric research communities, who are dedicated to promote enhanced understanding of the processes by which energy in the form of magnetic fields and particles are produced by the Sun and accelerated in interplanetary space, and on the mechanisms by which these fields and particles are transported to the Earth and elsewhere in the solar system.

SHINE research focuses upon the connection between events and phenomena on the Sun and their relation to solar wind structures in the heliosphere, as well as the origin and evolution of the solar wind, the nature of turbulence in the interplanetary medium, and the production and transport of solar energetic particles from the Sun through the heliosphere. The goal of SHINE activities is to enrich and strengthen our physical understanding of, and predictive capabilities for, such phenomena.

Over the course of this workshop support project, SHINE mentors and trains next-generation scientists, while facilitating the community's exchange of ideas and providing directions for future research. In addition to providing all logistical support for the workshop's activities, this specific five-year effort will fully fund the participation of at least 55 U.S. students and 5 U.S. postdoctoral fellows annually, as well as up to five foreign students and scientists able to make unique contributions to the SHINE science community. As a community-based research group engaged in space weather science, SHINE is also allied with other community science programs within the NSF that support research in magnetosphere physics, ionospheric physics, and aeronomy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The 2016 SHINE workshop was held in Santa Fe, NM from July 10 to 15, 2016. Through the two NSF awards supporting students participation at SHINE, we funded 68 US-based graduate students and young post-doctoral researchers (within 2 years of their PhD). This was the largest number of supported students in the 20 years of SHINE workshops and with more than 250 participants, the largest overall number of participants (about 35% increase from 2014 and 2015). 

Intellectual Merit: The SHINE workshop is the main workshop/conference for scientists working in solar and solar-terrestrial physics (heliospheric physics). There were 19 sessions at the 2016 SHINE workshop, ranging from eclipse observations to the outer heliosphere. Students took part in a student-only 1-day workshop, run by and for the students. 

Broader Impacts: The SHINE grant contributes to the education of a new generation of space scientists by funding graduate student participation in the SHINE workshop. Many of the former SHINE student participants are now active SHINE members (including through session organization), and members of the greater space community (incl. the PI as well as another member of the SHINE steering committee). The student-only day which is fully organized by and for the students and takes place on the Sunday before the start of the main SHINE workshop is a unique venue for students to work on their presentation skills, to learn more about solar and heliospheric physica and to form life-long collaboration.
